These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Several children including a baby are among about  people to have arrived after crossing the English Channel in small boats.The migrants, who have arrived at Dungeness, Kent, follow  people who were intercepted by the UK authorities on Monday .More than , people have crossed the Channel since the start of the year with , making the crossing in .The arrivals on Tuesday were brought ashore on an RNLI leboat with families wrapped in blankets and children being carried up the beach assisted by crew members and police officers. vw,vw,px, px"A young child among a group of people thought to be migrants is brought in to Dungeness, Kent, by the RNLI Minister for Justice and Tackling Illegal Migration, Tom Pursglove MP, said: “The rise in dangerous Channel crossings is unacceptable. Not only are they an overt abuse of our immigration laws but they also impact on the UK taxpayer, risk lives and our ability to help refugees come to the UK via safe and legal routes. Rightly, the British public has had enough.“Through our Nationality and Borders Bill, we’re cracking down on people smugglers and fixing the broken system by making it a criminal offence knowingly to arrive in the UK illegally and introducing a maximum sentence of le imprisonment for those who facilitate illegal entry into the country.”

title: detained-british-iranian-mother-nazanin-zaghari-ratcliffe-gets-passport-back
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Detained British-Iranian mother Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe has had her passport ed and a British negotiating team is in Tehran, her MP has said.Mrs Zaghari-Ratclfe has been detained in Iran since her arrest in  on charges of plotting to overthrow the government – allegations she has always denied.A £ million debt relating to a cancelled order for , Chieftain tanks dating back to the s had been linked to the continued detention of Mrs Zaghari-Ratclfe and other UK-Iranian dual nationals held in the country.On Tuesday, Hampstead and Kilburn MP Tulip Siddiq tweeted: “I am very pleased to say that Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe has been given her British passport back. She is still at her family home in Tehran. I also understand that there is a British negotiating team in Tehran right now. I will keep posting updates as I get them.”According to her employer, the Thomson Reuters Foundation, her lawyer Hojjat Kermani, when asked whether Mrs Zaghari-Ratclfe will be released, said: “I am hopeful that we will have good news soon.”I am very pleased to say that Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe has been given her British passport back.She is still at her family home in Tehran. I also understand that there is a British negotiating team in Tehran right now.I will keep posting updates as I get them.#FreeNazanin— Tulip SiddiqMarch , Mrs Zaghari-Ratclfe was arrested in Iran as she prepared to fly back to the UK, having taken her daughter Gabriella – then not even two years old – to see relatives.She was accused of plotting to overthrow the Iranian government and sentenced to five years in jail, spending four years in Tehran’s Evin Prison and one under house arrest.Her husband, Richard Ratclfe, spent  days on hunger strike last year in London to draw attention to his we’s case.In January, the daughter of another British-Iranian detained in Iran said her father was to begin a hunger strike due to a lack of progress in securing his release.Retired civil engineer Anoosheh Ashoori has been held at Evin Prison on charges of spying for Israel, which he denies, for more than four years.In a video posted in relation to the hunger strike, Elika Ashoori said she was at that time “extremely concerned” for her father’s health “as he approaches his th birthday”.In December, Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said the £ million that Britain owes Iran is a “legitimate debt” that the Government wants to pay. vw,vw,px, px"Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe Sacha Deshmukh, Amnesty International UK’s chief executive, warned that the latest reports should be treated with caution as there had been “ dawn after  dawn” in the long-running process.He said: “We sincerely hope these reports are correct.“The detainees and their families have been suffering for years, and a resolution can’t come quickly enough.“It’s been clear for a long time that the Iranian authorities have been targeting foreign nationals with spurious national security-related charges to exert diplomatic pressure.“In the past we’ve had  dawn after  dawn over possible breakthroughs, so it’s only right to be cautious at the moment.”Rupert Skilbeck, director of the Redress human rights organisation, also urged caution.He said: “The latest indications coming from Iran are a positive sign, but there have been  dawns in Nazanin’s case before. So we remain cautious and continue to encourage the UK Government to do the right thing and ensure the debt it owes to Iran is paid, and that it does everything in its power to secure Nazanin’s release.”In relation to the debt, the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office said: “We continue to explore options to resolve this case and will not comment further as discussions are ongoing.”On the cases of Britons detained, a Foreign Office spokesperson said: “We have long called for the release of unfairly detained British nationals in Iran. We don’t comment on speculation.”

title: sessions and sail to bring music to the swan later this year
story: An experience combining sailing and live music sessions will come to the isles for the first time in April. between th and th April.It will coincide with the th Shetland Folk Festival celebrations.The first voyage for Sessions and Sail took place in , but this is the first time it has been brought to the isles.Musician Nisbet said that the trip, initially booked for , had been #a long time coming#.#I’ve run trips further south and have always been keen to bring Sessions and Sail home,# he said. being such a well-known Shetland vessel, and having sailed on her regularly myself, I know she will be the perfect boat to partner with.#I am also delighted that for the sailing we will be under the command of skipper Maggie Adamson, who is a top class Shetland musician as well as an excellent sailor.#Swan Trust Trustee Brian Wishart said they were #delighted# to bring Sessions and Sail to the isles. is no stranger to musical sessions, with many a memorable night aboard.#We hope this trip may become an annual event, adding to the wide range of high-quality musical experiences on offer in Shetland.#..Twelve young Shetlanders will take part in the Tall Ships Races  which set off from Aalborg in Denmark next month.A group of  youngsters set off for an adventure of sailing and racing on board the Swan this afternoon – their first destination Hirtshals#Keen sailor Scott Sandison saw off global competition to be named Sail Training International Sail Trainer of the Year .Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: lace to compete at crufts for fifth time
story: A Sandwick woman and her seven-year-old dog will compete at Crufts in a Scottish team this week # for the fth time together.Sally Sanford and Lace, her Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retriever, will take part in the rally event on Thursday at the NEC in Birmingham.The pair are part of a Scotland team who will face Wales, Northern Ireland and four English regional teams in the inter-regional rally competition.The rally course sees dog and handler work as a pair to navigate a course of between  and  dferent exercises.Ms Sanford said the competition was always #a step-up#.#You#re asking the dogs to do stuff that isn#t that complicated for them, but it#s the handlers who need to be able to multi-task, to concentrate in the moment and navigate their way around the course.#You need your head in the game.#But she said that was one of Lace#s strengths, and said he had finished second in his event previously.The pair are hoping for another strong showing, but with Crufts taking place for the first time since March , she said there were some uncertainties.#None of us know how busy Crufts is going to be this year,# she said.#I would be lyingI said there wasn#t a degree of trepidation.#She said that she was excited for theof the #enormous# event, though, and hopes Lace will be able to inspire Scotland to better their previous best performance of third...Pet pooches are being given the chance to test their agility and obedience without even having to leave their own gardens – proving that lockdownSandwick resident Sally Sanford will be appearing at the Crufts dog show this week as part of the Scottish rally team with her Nova ScotiaA dog lover from Bigton says that making the final in the Kennel Club’s Eukanuba Friends for Le competition at Crufts  would mean the#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: northlink highlights likely ferry delays
story: NorthLink have issued a further warning over possible delays.The ferry operator says tonight#s [Sunday#s] northbound sailing of the Hrossey may fail to arrive on time at Kirkwall.It says the vessel, which is due to leave Aberdeen at pm, may not reach Orkney for up to an hour after its scheduled arrival time.Meanwhile, the southbound sailing of the Hjaltland is scheduled to depart Lerwick for Aberdeen at pm.But NorthLink has warned her arrival in Aberdeen may be subject to weather related delays.Freight services could also be impacted by the conditions.NorthLink says the Helliar#s pm departure from Aberdeen could be delayed...Tonight’sfreight sailing from Lerwick to Aberdeen has been cancelled due to adverse weather.NorthLink has warned customers of more weather-related disruption lasting through the weekend and into next week. The ferry operator said todayrsquossouthbound passenger sailing#NorthLink’s southbound ferry sailing tomorrowis under review with a “high possibility” of cancellation.Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: yell sound service to operate for foot passengers only
story: Vehicles will be accommodated on an inter-island ferry across Yell Sound tomorrow [Monday], despite earlier concerns that the service would be restricted to foot passengers only.Shetland Islands Council apologised earlier after problems with the linkspan at Ulsta were highlighted.At that point it advised that a single vessel would operate, but just for foot passengers.But chairman of the council#s environment and transport committee, Ryan Thomson, says the fault has now been found, meaning vehicles will be allowed to cross after all.As things stand, tomorrow will see a single vessel service operate across Yell Sound, with a full ro-ro service for vehicles.Passengers are being asked to double-check tomorrow before travelling, by using the voicebank on  .Mr Thomson has apologised for the #mixed messages# that have been sent.#It was important to keep you all posted with the latest information and advice so people can prepare accordingly,# he said...Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.Concerns have been raised after Shetland was excluded from Scottish government plans for fixed links.North Isles councillor Ryan Thomson says work on fixed links should begin in the next council term.A senior councillor has demanded NorthLink reverse its decision to scrap islander discounts on food and drink. title: nominations open for election candidates
story: The door is being opened today [Monday] for potential councillors seeking to put themselves forward for election.Shetland will choose who will be its representatives when the local authority elections take place across the country on th May., which was officially unveiled last week.Council convener Malcolm Bell urged anyone tempted to stand for election to #seriously consider# doing so.“A healthy local democracy depends on people putting themselves forward when elections come around,# he said.#As the period for nominations open, I urge anyone who thinks they have something to give to seriously consider standing at this election.#The nomination process is itself is straightforward and there is a wealth of information available online about what a councillor’s work is like.#I will stand for where I spent half my le#s work, Lerwick North and Bressay ward...Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.The doors have been thrown open at the St Ringan#s church # the new home of the council chamber.Shetland Islands Council convener Malcolm Bell has said he will not stand for re-election next May. The former policeman has been both councillor and convener#An extra councillor could be elected to the Town Hall next year, giving the SIC  elected representatives. title: cunningsburgh show to make welcome return
story: The Cunningsburgh Show is to make aon th August.The show committee has confirmed plans to push ahead with this year#s flagship agricultural event.It follows an absence of two years because of the coronavirus pandemic.But earlier this year the committee said it had plans to bring the show back for .Other agricultural shows are also likely to follow suit.Society president Alex Dodge said: #The society is delighted to be able to have the show this year. #After two years of no activity, we hope that the show will be a welcome event in Shetland#s calendar.#..Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.This year#s Cunningsburgh Show will not be held. The key event in Shetland#s agricultural calendar has been called off for the second consecutive year. Committee#The cancellation of Shetland#s agricultural shows due to Covid- is a #real loss# to the farming sector and local communities.The Cunningsburgh and Districts Agricultural Society will defy coronavirus restrictions by hosting a virtual show. Lockdown regulations meant the county show was cancelled earlier this#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: lerwick harbour workers vote to strike
story: Twelve Lerwick Port Authorityworkers have unanimously voted to strike and ban overtime # potentially bringing the harbour to #an absolute standstill#.The union Unite said the overtime ban would have a #severe impact# on cruise ships and oil and gas vessels looking to visit the harbour.The workers, which includes engineers, electricians, joiners and general operatives, have taken the decision because of a dispute over pay, terms and conditions.The continuous overtime ban will start from Monday, th March.Unite general secretary Sharon Graham said the unanimous decision to strike should make it clear to the LPA that the workers #can no longer be taken for granted#.#We know the business can well afford to pay our members what they deserve. So, management needs toto the table with an improved offer immediately,# she said.And industrial officer John Clark said the decision to strike was #a reflection of the anger our members feel#.#An overtime ban in itself will massively disrupt the operations at Lerwick port because of the extra hours required to ensure the smooth running of operations.#If there is no progress in the coming weeks, we also reserve the right to take all out strike action which will bring the port to an absolute standstill.#..Lerwick Port Authority workers are set to vote on possible industrial action in the coming weeks over pay. Engineers, electricians and joiners are among the#The cruise season is set to get off to its earliest ever start next week with the arrival of Viking Venus.Lerwick Harbour has seen signs of recovery in the last quarter, despite ongoing challenges.Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: injury marrs shinty return as newtonmore defender requires surgery after blow to the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFowler appeared to be knocked out after taking a blow to the head in the closing seconds of the game.The injury would require surgery in Aberdeen on Sunday morning, after the player was transfered from Raigmore in Inverness on Saturday evening. An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: is northern ireland on track to reach its climate change targets
story: The road to net zero is littered with obstacles as political parties lock horns over a ban on smoky coal and other environmental issues. In the absence of an Executive, some ambitions have been thwartedExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseA protester at Stormont as the Climate Bill was being discussed. Credit: Liam McBurneyPeople in fancy dress protest about the state of the notorious Mobuoy dump on the outskirts of Londonderry FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA protester at Stormont as the Climate Bill was being discussed. Credit: Liam McBurneyGarrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailProgress on climate legislation has been slow and arduous in Northern Ireland, in part due to its dependence on agriculture, an industry responsible for % of greenhouse gas emissions.A bill has now been passed but does it go far enough and what targets does Northern Ireland need to meet in order to secure real change that would benefit both the environment and public health Climate change billNorthern Ireland has finally brought itself in line with every other country in Western Europe by approving its own climate change legislation.Late progress was made in this Assembly mandate however there was some criticism that Northern Ireland remains an exception in delivering net-zero ambitions.MLAs passed an amendment tabled by Minister Edwin Poots which caps the target for methane emissions.The Minister argued that cutting cattle herds was not an option, particularly with an escalating crisis in Ukraine which could impact food supplies in Northern Ireland.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up His amendment sets a separate target for methane as part of wider ambitions for net zero emissions by . It means that methane emissions for  are not required to be more than % lower than the  baseline. The law now needs to be implemented.Read MoreAssembly passes climate Bill committing Northern Ireland to net zero by Tree coverageNorthern Ireland ranks badly as one of the least-wooded regions in Europe, with just % woodland cover compared with the European average of %. In addition, almost % of our woodland is in the form of recent coner plantations.The Woodland Trust said Northern Ireland needs to signicantly increase tree plantingit is to help towards a UK woodland target.The conservation charity previously published its Emergency Tree Plan. The plan sets out how the UK can rapidly increase tree cover to help reach net zero carbon emissions and tackle the declines in wildle.Northern Ireland would need to plant , hectares of trees a year to hit an existing target of % cover by . To contribute to this, the Forests For our Future Programme announced by Mr Poots in March  set targets to create , hectares of new woodland by , which falls well short of those recommended by the Woodland Trust.The Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairshas a woodland expansion target  hectares for  .Ammonia emissionsAmmonia is an air pollutant largely emitted from agriculture and has a damaging impact on bioersity, including sensitive habitats, as well as human health. It is produced by many common farming activities, such as the housing of livestock, the storage and spreading of manure and slurries, and the application of fertiliser.An Audit Office report from February found that most areas of Northern Ireland, including designated sites and other priority habitats, are affected by high levels of nitrogen being deposited on land and into water surfaces.The levels in most areas are signicantly above what is considered their “critical load”, the concentration of nitrogen at which signicant ecological damage occurs. Northern Ireland is responsible for % of UK ammonia emissions, despite only having % of its population and % of its land area, and is the only region of the UK where ammonia levels have not been decreasing.“Failure to address the increasing level of ammonia emissions also has the potential to contribute to serious, long-term harm to the environment and human health,” the report concluded.Mr Poots has conceded that a failure to publish an Ammonia Reduction Strategywill be a regret when he leaves office and it is one that has left the department vulnerable to legal challenge. However, he stresses that he wants to publish a strategy before leaving office.Independent Environmental Protection AgencyUnder an outline programme for government in the New Decade, New Approach, a number of coordinated measures to reverse climate change were laid out.They included an Independent Environmental Protection Agencyto oversee targets that would be set as part of climate change legislation.Mr Poots is opposed to the establishment of an IEPA, believing it to be unnecessary bureaucracy. However, he has proposed setting up an office of environmental protection to do similar independent work.Conservation Management PlansNorthern Ireland is home to important nature and wildle, of both national and international importance, which are a key part of the Northern Ireland landscape, providing a wide range of goods and services to society and helping to deal with climate change.The UK faced formal infringement proceedings by the European Commission because of the failure to have in place Conservation Management Plansfor its European sites.There are  special areas of conservation and  special protection areas in Northern Ireland. Strangford Lough and Rathlin Island were reported to the commission as having a CMP in place.That leaves  sites without such plans in Northern Ireland.At the time of the infraction proceedings it was reported to the Commission Rathlin Island and Strangford Lough had Conservation Management Plansin place.The Commission took the view that developing CMPs for each of the remaining SACs would signicantly contribute to addressing the alleged failings to comply with the obligations under the Habitats Directive.DAERA subsequently embarked on a signicant programme of work to develop such CMPs to date draft CMPs have been developed for  of the SAC sites, with the intention to have draft plans for all SACs completed by December .Clear AirAir pollution is the top environmental risk to human health in the UK, and the fourth greatest threat to public health after cancer, heart disease and obesity.The Clean Air Strategy, published in January  by the UK Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs , sets out a number of objectives to improve air quality across the UK.Additionally, DAERA issued a Clean Air Strategy for Northern Ireland Discussion Document for public consideration in November . The period of public discussion closed in early .This strategy aims to build on existing improvements within Northern Ireland and seeks to tackle important cross-Departmental issues relating to transport, energy, agriculture, industry, local air quality management, and communications.An air quality strategy was anticipated but has not been published. Minister Poots says that recommendations await the next office holder.Mobuoy super dumpAt public meetings, government officials have been repeatedly challenged to urgently deal with an estimated one million cubic metres of waste at the Mobuoy “super dump” on the outskirts of Derry. The River Faughan which forms the western boundary of the site supplies the city with % of its drinking water.Ongoing legal action has been blamed for delaying remediation work at the site. That trial is due to commence next month.The clean-up cost at Mobuoy has been estimated at a minimum of £ million — and potentially as much as £ million.NI Water and DAERA have always assured the public that chemicals present in drinking water are at safe levels. However, campaigners contend there are “no safe levels” of arsenic or manganese as exposure to such chemicals can have a long-term damaging effect on the brain.It is expected that based on successful approval of a business case, a remediation contractor will be appointed by late .Ban on petroleum licensingIn a somewhat unexpected move, the DUP Economy Minister, Gordon Lyons, announced that he would support a ban on fracking and onshore petroleum licensing activity in Northern Ireland.Fracking is broadly banned across the UK and Ireland. In England, the Government told the industry it would not agree to any future fracking “until compelling new evidence is provided” that it was safe.Two petroleum licensing applications in NI relate to Fermanagh, where a company called Tamboran Resources UK applied for a licence in .A separate application from EHA Exploration takes in five council areas: Belfast, Antrim and Newtownabbey, Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon, Lisburn and Castlereagh, and Mid Ulster.However, Sinn Fein said it is “bitterly disappointing” that as a result of the DUP collapsing the Executive, that ban cannot now be brought forward.Water pollutionA recent ‘Water Framework Directive Statistics Report’ determined that none of Northern Ireland’s  rivers, lakes and coastal waters achieved a “good overall status” rating for water quality.Environmentalists have argued that minimal fines handed down for water pollution do not act as an appropriate deterrent for repeat offenders.Figures obtained by Green Party MLA Rachel Woods showed that more than seven million tonnes of raw sewage is being dumped into Northern Ireland’s seas and rivers every year.NI Water requires investment of around £bn in water and wastewater services over a six year period, the Utility Regulator said in May. This financial year the DfI Minister allocated a combined budget £m to NI Water for  .Coal banSmoky coal is one of the worst causes of air pollution. It has been reported that approximately , premature deaths have been averted in Dublin since the introduction of a coal ban back in . In the past, DUP MP Sammy Wilson strongly opposed proposals saying that low-income households who use cheap coal would be adversely affected as smokeless coal costs more.In response, then Environment Minister Mark H Durkan said: “It is great to hear Saint Sammy, defender of the disadvantaged — I do not know what happened to Sammy, the champion of the Tory cuts — make all these arguments on behalf of those suffering fuel poverty.“There is not a word about the big business interests of those in the coal business or, indeed, the interests of Larne port in his own constituency.”DUP MLA Michelle McIlveen, who was DAERA Minister before the Assembly collapsed, also said it was not her intention to ban smoky coal in the North.Now, Mr Poots, says he has no intention of banning coal because people would “die of hypothermia” in homes that are not properly insulated.Most Read Derry pupils end up locked in luggage compartment during school bus morning run… Translink has issued apologyLoyalist drug title: coronavirus northern ireland department of health wants covid 19 powers extended for further
story: Health Minister Robin Swann gives an update to the media at Stormont in February Pic Colm Lenaghan  Pacemaker Pic Colm Lenaghan  Pacemaker Pic Colm Lenaghan  Pacemaker FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueHealth Minister Robin Swann gives an update to the media at Stormont in February Pic Colm Lenaghan  Pacemaker Pic Colm Lenaghan  Pacemaker Pic Colm Lenaghan  PacemakerNiamh CampbellTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailNorthern Irelands Department of Health has set intentions to extend its Covid- powers for another half a year, with its current date for expiration due on March .The  Coronavirus Act, which was brought in at the start of the pandemic, initially had a two-year lespan and allowed the four UK nations specially tailored abilities to help carry out their Covid responses.The act is a legal tool to bring in restrictions, but without a ing Executive in place here it could be ineffective.Read More‘I’ll go with flabbergasted’: Parent reacts after  pupils get stuck in boot of busNorthern Ireland travel: All Covid restrictions for those entering UK to be scrapped from FridayLast month, Health Minister Robin Swann stressed the importance of being able to reintroduce coronavirus rulesnecessary, such ascases of a new iant begin to spike rapidly again.However, he admitted that the collapse of Stormont following Paul Givan’s resignation as First Minister, would make passing the legislation dficult.A Department of Healthspokesperson said Mr Swann had stated repeatedly that he does not wish to have to use these powers, however it is imperative that they are available to protect the public should they be required.As previously communicated to the executive, I intend to seek extended powers granted to the department by the Coronavirus Act , by six months, said Mr Swann in the Assembly on Monday.In line with that legislation, I plan to bring those measures before the House in the near future. I sincerely hope that these powers do not need to be used, but I cannot assume that there will be no need to protect the public from a new iant in future.Even with these powers in place, however, it would almost certainly be impossible to introduce new restrictions in the absence of an Executive.Read MoreUkraine: Northern Ireland politicians urge public to help home refugees as two leaders confirm they will sign up to schemeNew dining and nightle hotspot planned for ‘neglected’ Belfast district as £m ploughed into city centreThe DUP’s Paul Frew, who has been highly vocal with his previous criticisms of coronavirus regulations such as the vaccination certication scheme, called on the minister to justy the extension.I’ve just sat in the Assembly Chamber and heard the Health Minister slip in at the end of another motion that he intends to bring another motion extending his extensive and unaccountable powers for a further six months. Unbelievable— Paul FrewMarch , This minister now wants to extend his powers, in the midst of an election period where there is no Executive and there will be no assembly to hold the minister to account. Now I don#t think that#s sufficient, I don#t think that#s appropriate, the North Antrim MLA commented.Mr Swann told Mr Frew that he would get the opportunity to have his say on the issue as he had already requested an Assembly debate on the extension.There was accusations made about me slipping something in and not for a full debate. I think what I was actually using was taking this opportunity to flag that the debate was coming.The chair of the health committee, the members of the health committee are aware that this is going to be brought and I have tabled that before.It#s been tabled through the Business Office and I#m seeking now that it is actually brought to the business table or business committee for scheduling so I#ll be here to have that debate, Mr Swann added.A Department of Healthspokesperson said its minister had stated repeatedly that he does not wish to have to use these powers, however it is imperative they are available to protect the public should they be required.They said no objections had been raised by other ministers against the extension.Most Read Derry pupils end up locked in luggage compartment Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium  Derry pupils end up locked in luggage compartment during school bus morning run… Translink has issued apologyBus was bringing children to Oakgrove Integrated College when incident occurredExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseOakgrove Integrated Collage. Image Google FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueOakgrove Integrated Collage. Image GoogleGarrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailTranslink has issued an apology to schoolchildren and sought to reassure parents after it emerged that  young pupils ended up in the luggage compartment of a bus on the morning school run.The Belfastwas told that a double decker bus arrived to transport children on Friday morning, March , at Top of the Hill in the Waterside area of Londonderry. Pupils from Oakgrove Integrated College were waiting to get on the bus.However, the driver informed them that the main door was broken and they would have to use an emergency door at the back of the bus. It’s understood that a baggage area was opened by mistake.According to information provided, around  pupils either knowingly, or unknowingly, entered the baggage area and ‘kept crawling through’ in an effort to gain access.Read More‘I’ll go with flabbergasted’: Parent reacts after  pupils get stuck in boot of busIntegrated Education Bill is shameful, claims DUP’s Edwin PootsThe door shut behind them and the bus continued on its journey towards the college situated at Stradreagh.Some time later other children on the bus heard the children shouting from underneath and informed the driver.Pupils were required to give witness statements afterwards and it’s been alleged that one or two ended up with aches and pains.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up In a statement to the Belfast , Translink said it is currently investigating a “recent incident involving pupils on a school bus service” in Derry.“These pupils did not receive the level of customer care they should have been given, and we apologise unreservedly to these young passengers for this inconvenience,” a spokesperson continued.“We carry over , young people to and from school every day, and safety is our top priority. This was an unfortunate isolated incident and we will be following up with the young passengers involved.“We would like to reassure all young people, their parents, carers and school representatives that we have taken steps to ensure this will not happen again.”Oakgrove Integrated College was founded by local parents and opened in September .The College has full Grant Maintained status. It is co-educational and its distinctive feature is the planned integrated character.The school is located at a -acre site in the grounds of Gransha Park overlooking the River Foyle and is surrounded by sports pitches, playing areas, wooded areas, shrub areas and a College Green. A spokesperson for Oakgrove Integrated College said “We were made aware of an incident on Friday th March once students arrived at the school.Oakgrove immediately contacted the organisation responsible, as well as the appropriate department within the Education Authority and we await a response from the service provider at this stage.We can make no further comment until we fully understand what happened and the steps that are being taken to address it.”Most Read Derry pupils end up locked in luggage title: covid 19 travel restrictions to be lifted in
story: All international travel restrictions will be scrapped . FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueAll international travel restrictions will be scrapped .Garrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailAll international Covid- travel restrictions will be removed for those travelling to Northern Ireland.The change will come into effect from am on March .Travellers will also no longer be required to take tests or complete a Passenger Locator Form .The remaining managed hotel quarantine capacity will be fully stood down by the end of March.This move keeps Northern Ireland in line with other UK regions.Health Minister Robin Swann said: “I have always said I would not keep restrictions in place longer than necessary.As we continue to make steady steps out of the Covid restrictions, the removal of the International Travel Regulations will enable freer travel for all ahead of the Easter period.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Work will continue across the UK to identy and manage any potential iants that may emerge.Travellers who are feeling unwell are advised to follow the public health advice and should not travel.Travellers to other countries should continue to follow the restrictions set out by the country they are visiting.Most Read Derry FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueQUB said it “continually reviews its suppliers and how their service fits with value for money, as well as supporting local business and a sustainable future for all”.Thomas CopelandMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailQueen’s University Belfastspent more than £, on nearly , Amazon purchases during the pandemic.Nearly one in three transactions made using QUB staff purchasing cards between August  and July  were credited to the online retail giant, Freedom of Information requests have revealed.This has been met with criticism from some QUB staff and students who say that Amazon has a damaging impact on the environment and on local businesses.The university said it “continually reviews its suppliers and how their service fits with value for money, as well as supporting local business and a sustainable future for all”.According to its Strategy , QUB is committed to “reaching net-zero carbon emissions as soon as possible”.Professor John Barry, director of the Centre for Sustainability, Equality and Climate Action at QUB said: “It’s hypocritical. The university, like a lot of corporate institutions, puts out these statements with rhetorical commitments to sustainable development. Like the Irish football team, it’s great on paper but crap on grass.“These are goods that have been made God knows where in the world, warehoused in Belgium or London and then sent over here. All of that has a carbon cost.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Amazon’s latest carbon footprint report detailed that the company’s emissions increased by % in  to more than  million metric tons, equal to the annual emissions of Austria.QUB would not disclose information on the products bought and on Amazon purchases made by staff that were subsequently refunded by the university.It did say that the purchasing cards are “a payment system used by the university to support low-value and high-volume purchases.Not all staff are issued with a purchasing card.However, according to Professor Barry, “that just opens up more questions than answers”.At Ulster University, less than one in  transactions using staff purchasing cards were credited to Amazon in the same period, totalling around £,.“Small businesses like mine have struggled during the pandemic”, said Jenny Steele, a QUB student and business owner.“Yet we have been ignored by Queen’s in favour of cheap products and cheap labour. Despite making promises to support local businesses, Queen’s has turned to unethical and unsustainable suppliers like Amazon.”Professor Barry added: “Queen’s made £m over the pandemic from international student fees. “I do not accept that the university could not afford to pay more for goods from local businesses.”QUB said it has “contracted suppliers for a wide range of goods and services and these suppliers should be approached in the first instance. In the event that a contracted supplier is not in a position to fulfil a requirement, alternative suppliers are permitted”.Some students have moved to defend QUB.  First-year student Sam Haslett said: “During the pandemic, everyone used Amazon far more.“If Queen’s is guilty of damaging the environment or local businesses, then we all are. Plus loads of small businesses now sell through Amazon anyway.”The online retailer reported that around , small and medium-sized enterprises in Northern Ireland exported more than £m in goods through Amazon in .A  report estimated that QUB contributes £.bn to the UK economy every year.Most Read Derry pupils end up locked in luggage compartment during school bus morning run… Translink has issued title: parents staggered to find derry creche locked and children refused entry
story: Bridie Canning holds her daughter, Ruaand her friend Mia Butleroutside Rosemount Resource Centre which they found closed this morning when they tried to attend creche. Picture Martin McKeown FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBridie Canning holds her daughter, Ruaand her friend Mia Butleroutside Rosemount Resource Centre which they found closed this morning when they tried to attend creche. Picture Martin McKeownGarrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailParents arriving to drop their children off at a crèche in Derry were shocked to find they had been locked out of the building.On Tuesday morning parents stood outside Treehouse Crèche in protest at what was happening and demanded answers.The same childcare facility, which looks after the needs of  children, was threatened with closure in  due to a dispute between management and staff at Rosemount Resource Centre .Mother Bridie Canning was due to leave her three-year-old daughter Rua off there.She said: “I don’t know what is going on at the centre. I landed with my daughter and the gates were closed. A car was parked across the entrance and the children weren’t allowed in.“We weren’t given any notice of this as parents. Rua is asking me questions about why she was wasn’t allowed in but it’s hard to explain to a three-year-old.“Parents were staggered by the fact it was closed.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up She added: “People who are working would have had to take the day off to look after their children.“I hope whatever has happened is going to be resolved. My wee boy who is eight now also attended Treehouse. It’s a great crèche and there are never any problems with it.”Chairman of Derry Trades Union Council and UNISON community and voluntary branch, Niall McCarroll was in attendance in support of workers and affected families at the centre in Creggan.He told the Belfast : “Parents who turned up with the children this morning, and workers, arrived to find the gates were locked.“Our members contacted us to say they were met with a placard which said the crèche was closed.“Two people were trying to give out letters to parents.“As far as we are concerned this has left workers unable to do their jobs and we will be providing whatever support we can.”After a standoff, children were eventually granted entry to the crèche.Last year a letter was sent to iniduals responsible for running Treehouse Crèche.It advised staff members thatthey did not cooperate with RRC management then they would have “no alternative but to close the facility in the interests of child protection and safeguarding”.In the correspondence, which was shared on social media, RRC management said they had asked to meet Treehouse employees to discuss staff ratios, staff training, inidual education plans, and safeguarding and child protection.The letter added: “I do not understand the action being taken by you as staff since your only standing is as employees of the Rosemount Resource Centre.”That development came after a split was revealed between the management committee and staff at RRC.Ten members of staff from RRC signed a letter of ‘no confidence’ in the management committee.A list of grievances and concerns were laid out over two-and-a-half pages.The letter was sent to the local council and circulated amongst councillors.In response, a solicitor acting on behalf of the management committee asked the council to “address this issue”.Workers who signed the letter say they have provided a collective  years’ service to the local community.It’s understood that the créche formed its own independent board, however, RRC still own the building.The Department for Communities and Rosemount Resource Centre have been contacted for comment.Most Read Derry pupils end up locked in luggage compartment title: unionists hail government u turn over united kingdom to great britain customs switch
story: UUP leader Doug Beattie. Credit: Liam McBurney FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueUUP leader Doug Beattie. Credit: Liam McBurneyStaff ReporterMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailUnionists have welcomed a climbdown by the Government over customs regulations that proposed changing all mentions of “the United Kingdom” to “Great Britain” — deliberately omitting Northern Ireland.Sky News reported that Foreign Secretary and UK Brexit negotiator Liz Truss had ordered officials to investigate how the statutory instrumentwas allowed to get to that point without “proper political scrutiny”.In multiple amendments to the The Customs Regulations , it was proposed that instead of using the words “the United Kingdom” that “Great Britain” should be used instead.The Government had presented the amendments as minor and insignicant and would ensure NI-GB trade could “continue smoothly”.The move provoked uproar online, as critics noted that this would directly contradict the Government’s position on the Northern Ireland Protocol by entrenching it further.Ulster Unionist leader Doug Beattie said he thought the initial move was “reprehensible by this Tory Government”.“Why on earth would we trust them, where is the sense in handing power to them ” he asked.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “We must stand our ground and represent the people of Northern Ireland within the Union — not give up for political expediency.”Conservative MP Steve Baker said Article  of the Withdrawal Agreement “makes clear that Northern Ireland is part of the customs territory of the UK. This was a crucial concession from the EU.“I know from my recent trip to Belfast that temperatures are running incredibly high among the unionist community. We cannot forget that the Belfast Agreement operates east-west as well as north-south.“This SI suggests that we are waving the white flag on the NI Protocol.”Northern Irish Labour peer Baroness Hoey tweeted: “Are there any Conservative MPs who care about the Union ”After news of the U-turn filtered through after Ms Truss’ intervention, Mr Beattie tweeted: “Engagement works and must be shown to work.“Without a voice we have no influence, without a voice we cannot outline the problems, without a voice we rely on those who do not have our best interests at heart. Let’s not throw away our voice.”Sky News deputy political editor Sam Coates said what had happened was “raising eyes at the Treasury, whose amendment it was”.Related topicsNI ProtocolDoug BeattieUlster Unionist PartyMore On title: uup leader too unwell to attend st patricks day events in washington
story: Doug Beattie  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDoug Beattie By Dominic McGrath, PAMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailDoug Beattie will not travel to the US for St Patrick’s Day celebrations as the Ulster Unionist Party leader is “too unwell” to attend.The UUP confirmed on Monday evening that Mr Beattie will not be travelling to Washington, which traditionally sees an influx of Irish politicians to mark the feast day of the country’s patron saint.A party spokesperson said Mr Beattie was “too unwell” to travel but stressed that the move was not a “snub”.The spokesperson said: “Doug is too unwell to travel to Washington and a lot of the events are non-transferable.Read MoreUkraine: Northern Ireland politicians urge public to help home refugees as two leaders confirm they will sign up to schemeIntegrated Education Bill is shameful, claims DUP’s Edwin Poots“The Ulster Unionist Party remains committed to ongoing engagement with the US government, officials and all those who have Northern Ireland’s best interests at heart.“This is not a snub, in fact quite the opposite, and we regret that our party leader is unable to take up the invitation on this occasion.“It would have been an ideal opportunity to follow up on our last series of engagements in the United States after Doug Beattie led an Ulster Unionist delegation to Washington and New York in November .Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “We wish those attending this week’s events a happy St Patrick`s Day and we look forward to taking up future invitations and opportunities to engage directly with the US administration.”Taoiseach Micheal Martin will meet US President Joe Biden later this week as part of the traditional visit of the Irish premier to the White House.Most Read Derry pupils end up locked Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownPoliticsGeneral Election RHI ScandalBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium New Civil Service chief silent over whistleblower caseDAERA appealing judgment that vet who raised fraud and animal welfare concerns was forced outExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseCivil Service head Jayne Brady. Credit: Liam McBurneyDr Tamara Bronckaers FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCivil Service head Jayne Brady. Credit: Liam McBurneySam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailThe new head of the Civil Service has declined to say whether it is acceptable for a Stormont department to attempt to overturn a judicial finding that a civil servant was driven from her job after she blew the whistle on potential fraud and animal suffering.Last week the Belfastrevealed the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairswas using taxpayers’ money to attempt to overturn a devastating judgment that raised serious concerns about Northern Ireland’s chief vet and one of his deputies.Six months ago an employment tribunal unanimously found that Tamara Bronckaers, a senior DAERA vet with an “exemplary performance and record”, had been constructively sacked because she blew the whistle.The case has major implications for the treatment of Civil Service whistleblowers, the welfare of animals, the spread of disease, and the reputation of the cattle traceability system which, since the BSE crisis, has been central to how the agriculture industry has marketed local beef.The public could be forced to pay £m to compensate her, along with huge legal bills.In a ,-word judgment, Employment Judge Ó Murray repeatedly criticised the whistleblower’s treatment by two of her senior colleagues — line manager Julian Henderson and chief vet Robert Huey.At the heart of the case was Dr Bronckaers’ desire to pursue enforcement action against Ballymena Livestock Market over alleged suffering caused to animals, and animal movements being electronically deleted.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Dr Huey told her he knew the manager of the market personally and also its chairman. Both he and Dr Henderson discouraged her from pursuing enforcement, with Dr Bronckaers left in tears after an encounter with Dr Huey. Both men remain in post, while Dr Bronckaers does not. The Belfastasked Dr Bradyas head of the Civil Service she had anything to say about whether, on her watch, this will be acceptable, and whether she has any message to other whistleblowers.In response the Executive Office, within which the head of the Civil Service sits, responded: “It is not appropriate to comment on an ongoing legal issue which is a matter for DAERA.”Dr Brady, who was brought in from Belfast City Council, was appointed last year.Three months ago she told an Assembly committee that one of her key priorities was to deliver the recommendations of the RHI Inquiry, and said “of course we’re all aware of the whistleblowing legislation”.There was no suggestion that Dr Bronckaers was anything other than genuine, and the Civil Service handbook makes clear that whistleblowers should be encouraged.It states that the organisation “encourages staff to raise issues of concern internally to provide an opportunity to have such matters investigated and addressed as appropriate. Reasonable belief that wrongdoing has taken place is sufficient justication… It will always be assumed that concerns have been raised in good faith unless there is evidence to the contrary”.It adds that officials “should not suffer any detriment or harassment as a result.”If DAERA loses its appeal, taxpayers will fund Dr Bronckaers’ compensation, which could be as much as £m, plus hefty legal bills.Related topicsNorthern Ireland AssemblyDepartment of Agriculture, Environment  Rural Affairs - The Executive OfficeMore On Northern Ireland AssemblyIntegrated Education Bill is shameful, claims Credit: Liam McBurney PA Wire"srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news politics bfd .ece AUTOCROP w Renewable%Heat%Incentive%inquiry...Copies%of%the%published%report%from%Sir%Patrick%Coghlins%Renewable%Heat%Incentive%RHI%public%inquiry%outside%Stormont%in%Belfast.%PA%Pho w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news politics bfd .ece AUTOCROP w Renewable%Heat%Incentive%inquiry...Copies%of%the%published%report%from%Sir%Patrick%Coghlins%Renewable%Heat%Incentive%RHI%public%inquiry%outside%Stormont%in%Belfast.%PA%Pho w" sizes"auto"  Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose public inquiry outside Stormont in Belfast. Credit: Liam McBurney PA Wire"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news politics bfd .ece AUTOCROP w Renewable%Heat%Incentive%inquiry...Copies%of%the%published%report%from%Sir%Patrick%Coghlins%Renewable%Heat%Incentive%RHI%public%inquiry%outside%Stormont%in%Belfast.%PA%Pho w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news politics bfd .ece AUTOCROP w Renewable%Heat%Incentive%inquiry...Copies%of%the%published%report%from%Sir%Patrick%Coghlins%Renewable%Heat%Incentive%RHI%public%inquiry%outside%Stormont%in%Belfast.%PA%Pho w" data-sizes"auto"   public inquiry outside Stormont in Belfast. Credit: Liam McBurney PA Wire"Copies of the published report from Sir Patrick Coghlin#s Renewable Heat Incentivepublic inquiry outside Stormont in Belfast. Credit: Liam McBurney PA Wire FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCopies of the published report from Sir Patrick Coghlin#s Renewable Heat Incentivepublic inquiry outside Stormont in Belfast. Credit: Liam McBurney PA WireSam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailStormont is on course to waste at least £m — and perhaps as much as £m — over the next  years due to its failure to find a way to spend Treasury funding made available to Northern Ireland for subsidising renewable heat.As revealed by the Belfastlast week, £m has already been wasted in this way and there is no sign of the Department for the Economy producing an alternative proposal for how it can spend the money.However, new figures show the vast scale of the waste aheadthe situation remains unaltered. In response to a Freedom of Information request from the Renewable Heat Association— which represents most RHI claimants — the department said that it was now on course to underspend by around £m. However, those figures only cover expenditure until , yet the GB RHI scheme — from whose budget Northern Ireland’s share of money for renewable heat is derived — has been extended and will not now close until .Based on that longer duration for the GB scheme, RHANI has calculated that Northern Ireland’s underspend may be closer to £m.Read MoreCriticism as Queen’s University Belfast ‘spends over £k’ on Amazon during pandemicThe hidden RHI scandal of how Stormont wasted £m in green energy subsidiesThe department said that it “will explore the potential to utilise any available [Treasury] funds in support of alternative or additional actions to decarbonise heat”. However, there is still no suggestion that this work has reached an advanced stage nor even that it will be possible because the Executive remains unable to decide how to handle existing RHI claimants.Those claimants were promised unalterable payments for  years but once the calamitous scale of the RHI overspend became apparent, Stormont abandoned that promise and retrospectively slashed their payments, meaning the actual overspend was £.m.That decision made them far less well rewarded than their counterparts in Great Britain or the Republic of Ireland, which recently launched its own version of RHI — putting Northern Irish businesses at a competitive disadvantage.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Sources within the DUP suggest that the party is split on how to handle the situation. Former leader Arlene Foster — the minister who set up the disastrous scheme but then said she was “accountable but not responsible” for the mess which followed — had endorsed a policy of throwing all RHI claimants out of the scheme, paying them a fraction of what they were originally promised as compensation. Sinn Fein has also endorsed this policy, but other DUP figures believe it is unfair to those claimants who entered the scheme in good faith, took on huge loans at the suggestion of its minister and government officials, and who did not abuse RHI.There is another factor which might explain the decision not to spend such a vast sum of money. The retrospective cuts to subsidies which had been guaranteed were immediately challenged in court by claimants. However, that process has moved tortoise-like over the last five years and has not yet gone to the Supreme Court. That case is just one of several RHI legal actions, the outcome of which the department cannot be certain.It may be that its decision not to launch a new green heat scheme is a way of hedging against the possibility that the original scheme is reinstated and it faces a vast compensation bill.Whatever the reason, it is having an increasingly stark impact. As oil and gas prices soar, renewables are among the cheapest alternatives — but have high up-front costs to install, which is why subsidies are in place where across the UK and Ireland.RHANI executive chairman Andrew Trimble said: “If civil servants had not removed  words from the national legislation on renewable heat when the NI legislation was implemented, then today we would have a strong, sustainable, environmentally friendly renewable heat sector. We would be contributing to our pathway to net zero and have a vastly reduced reliance on fossil fuels — with their polluting emissions reduced by %.”He said that Stormont could solve the problem by reinstating the missing  words — essentially replicating the GB scheme, with cost controls, something he said “could solve the political problems that Stormont and the department have created for themselves and for the people of Northern Ireland”.Mr Trimble highlighted that in , a Commons committee inquiry branded the department’s actions “a raw deal”, but the department had repeatedly failed to help genuine claimants suffering as a result of their broken promises.Related topicsDepartment for the EconomyThe Executive OfficeArlene FosterSinn FéinClimate ChangeMore On Department for the title: baby is among latest group of people to cross channel in small boats
story: A group of people thought to be migrants are brought in to Dungeness, Kent, by the RNLI following a small boat incident in the Channel on Tuesday  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA group of people thought to be migrants are brought in to Dungeness, Kent, by the RNLI following a small boat incident in the Channel on Tuesday By Ben Mitchell, PAMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailSeveral children including a baby are among about  people to have arrived after crossing the English Channel in small boats.The migrants, who have arrived at Dungeness, Kent, follow  people who were intercepted by the UK authorities on Monday .More than , people have crossed the Channel since the start of the year with , making the crossing in .The arrivals on Tuesday were brought ashore on an RNLI leboat with families wrapped in blankets and children being carried up the beach assisted by crew members and police officers."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk a .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_bcd-b--a-fbcfb_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk a .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_bcd-b--a-fbcfb_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk a .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_bcd-b--a-fbcfb_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news uk a .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_bcd-b--a-fbcfb_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "A young child among a group of people thought to be migrants is brought in to Dungeness, Kent, by the RNLI PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueA young child among a group of people thought to be migrants is brought in to Dungeness, Kent, by the RNLI Minister for Justice and Tackling Illegal Migration, Tom Pursglove MP, said: “The rise in dangerous Channel crossings is unacceptable. Not only are they an overt abuse of our immigration laws but they also impact on the UK taxpayer, risk lives and our ability to help refugees come to the UK via safe and legal routes. Rightly, the British public has had enough.“Through our Nationality and Borders Bill, we’re cracking down on people smugglers and fixing the broken system by making it a criminal offence knowingly to arrive in the UK illegally and introducing a maximum sentence of le imprisonment for those who facilitate illegal entry into the country.” Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletter Receive todays headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter. title: schools minister says we do need to talk about world as it is on trans rights
story: Schools Minister Robin Walker has said schools must teach LGBT content and that there are no plans to “rule out” teaching about trans issues  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSchools Minister Robin Walker has said schools must teach LGBT content and that there are no plans to “rule out” teaching about trans issues By Catherine Lough, PA Education CorrespondentMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailSchools Minister Robin Walker has said schools must teach LGBT content and that there are no plans to “rule out” teaching about trans issues.He told the Commons’ Education Committee: “We do need to talk about the world as it is”, adding that trans people were a protected group under the Equality Act who needed support.Conservative MP Miriam Cates asked why worked examples around the teaching of gender ideology had not been included in recent guidance to schools on political impartiality.We need to talk about the fact that people do transition and that there are trans people, and we should support them as a protected group under the Equality Act. We#re not going to rule out people teaching about thatRobin Walker“I very much welcome the new political guidance that’s been put out to schools. I completely agree – we should let children be children we shouldn’t be pushing adult political agendas in schools,” she said.She added that in the guidance there were  worked examples of issues around impartiality that could occur in schools about racism, dferent political systems, environmentalism and other topical issues.But she added that what was “conspicuous by its absence” was any example relating to the teaching of gender ideology, “by which I mean schools teaching against guidance that there are more than two sexes, that you can change sex, thatyou are gender non-conforming it might mean that you are the opposite sex to what you are biologically”.She said that anecdotally, parents had written to her expressing concern that “schools are transitioning pupils without their parents’ knowledge” and that this included pupils who might be gay and lesbian, or on the autism spectrum.She askedthe guidance could be updated to reflect this, and whether the Department for Education would investigate these reports.Schools minister Robin Walker said: “The first thing I’d say is that schools should not be teaching ideology, regardless of in what space that is, and I think we’re pretty clear about that in the political impartiality guidance.“We want schools to be able to support pupils, including the small number of pupils who may have gender identity issues and may need support in that respect, and it’s important thatthey approach members of staff they can be signposted to the right advice and support,” he added.He said that issues around sex and gender had to be taught in an “age-appropriate way” and that there were some “really complex legal issues to do with the Equality Act in this space”.The Government was working with the Equality and Human Rights Commissionto explore this, he said.“I think it’s important that we balance responsibility to protected characteristics of sex with the protected characteristic of gender reassignment, which is also protected under the Equality Act, and we make sure that we address the concerns that parents may have in this space,” he said.Responding to Ms Cates’ view that DfE guidance was clear “you can’t tell children you can change sex”, he said: “You said you’re not supposed to tell pupils that they can change sex – of course, you can do that, because you are supposed to teach LGBT content. You should not teach them that they should change sex.”He later claried that he had used “sex” and “gender” interchangeably but added: “We do need to talk about the world as it is.”“We need to talk about the fact that people do transition and that there are trans people, and we should support them as a protected group under the Equality Act. We’re not going to rule out people teaching about that,” he said.He added that the DfE should be “making sure it’s taught in an appropriate way and making sure it’s not encouraging something which would be medically dficult and could have implications for people’s mental health”.MP Tom Hunt said that it appeared that the guidance may not have “sufficient teeth” to make a dference, referring to the recent downgrading by Ofsted of the American School in London for its focus on “social justice” in its teaching.He asked whether Ofsted would make similar judgments when it came to state schools.Mr Walker said Ofsted was a separate entity but that the Government had published the guidance “for a reason” and that he believed most schools did not want to tell their pupils what to think or go into “politically contentious territory”.Labour MP Kim Johnson described the new guidance as “unnecessary” as schools had already been aware of their responsibility to be impartial.Elsewhere in the session, Mr Walker said that the low uptake of the National Tutoring Programme through the tuition partners route could be due to staff absence.“I recognise that particularly during the first half of this term, many schools were probably under too much pressure from staff absence in order to be able to engage with a programme like this to the extent we might like them to have done.”Robert Halfon, chair of the Commons’ Education Committee, said that the high levels of satisfaction with the programme reported by schools was akin to “truck production in the Soviet Union” given how unevenly spread tuition uptake was across the country.
